\def\spacingset#1{ \renewcommand{\baselinestretch} {#1}\small\normalsize} \spacingset{1}

\if1{1}
{
  \title{\bf Multiple Outliers in Small Samples}
  \author{Mark Chamness and Rachel Traylor\thanks{
    The authors gratefully acknowledge EMC for supporting this
    research}\hspace{.2cm}\\
    EMC Corporation\\
    }
  \maketitle
} \fi

\if0{1}
{
  \bigskip
  \bigskip
  \bigskip
  \begin{center}
    {\LARGE\bf Multiple Outliers in Small Samples }
\end{center}
  \medskip
} \fi

\bigskip
\begin{abstract}

Z-scores are often employed in outlier detection in a dataset. For small
samples, the presence of multiple outliers forces a finite supremum on the
absolute value of possible z-scores that decreases with an increasing number of
outliers, creating a ``masking effect'' that hinders identification of true outliers. We give an
illustrative case study in which the accurate detection of the number of
outliers is critical, and provide a closed form expression of the maximum
possible z-score in terms of the sample size and number of outliers. In
addition, a corresponding analysis on the $t-$statistic is performed. 
\end{abstract}

\noindent
{\it Keywords:}  Largest Z-score; Upper bound; Lower bound; Masking;
Multiple Outliers.
\vfill
 
\newpage
\spacingset{1.45} 
\section{Introduction}
\label{sec:intro}
Detection of outliers is a common first step in any data analysis across
disciplines. Outliers may be the statistic of interest (\cite{Energy, BMI}), or
the researchers may desire to eliminate outliers (\cite{Proteins, Autism}).
Multiple outliers inflate the sample variance, particularly for small sample
sizes, making correct outlier identification difficult. Maximum z-scores for
single outliers has been studied by \cite{doi:10.1080/00031305.1988.10475530}
for small sample sizes.
This paper generalizes maximum z-scores for multiple outliers, investigates the
asymptotic behavior of such maxima, and proposes a method for sample size
determination under which the z-score may be used. Since the $t-$statistic is
commonly employed when the $z-$score is deemed inappropriate, a corresponding
analysis is performed, noting that the $t-$score is also somewhat beholden to
this masking effect. A case study is presented whereupon the detection of
multiple outliers is critical to the investigation.
\par 
The paper is organized as follows. Section~\ref{sec:case study} provides the
case study of the relative performance of HDDs in a RAID group for enterprise
data storage systems for which the detection of multiple outliers is critical.
In Section~\ref{sec:anal}, we present a theorem that gives a formula for the
supremum of the absolute value of possible z-scores in terms of the sample
size and the number of outliers, and provide an asymptotic analysis of this
formula. A corollary for the $t-$ statistic is also presented. We also provide a
method for effective sample size determination under which a z-score may be used in outlier detection with reasonable confidence.
Section~\ref{sec:conc} gives the conclusion. 


\section{Case Study: Performance Degradation of Disk Drives} 
\label{sec:case study}
During the investigation of a large data set, it was discovered that the
distribution of a Z-statistic truncated sharply at 3.474.  It seemed
there must be a special reason for this abrupt truncation.
However, the team that provided the data didn't consider the truncation
important and suggested the upper bound was caused by physical constraints. 
Intuition suggested there was a more compelling reason.  This paper 
shows that it is a mathematical property which not only true for this data set,
but true for all small samples. \par
RAID (Redundant Array of Independent Disks) is a
technology that employs collections of disk drives and allows them to be used as a single logical unit.
By distributing data across many disks, RAID provides greater performance and
reliability than a single disk.
However, the performance of a RAID disk group is dependent on the performance of
each disk.
If a single disk experiences performance degradation the RAID group will also
degrade in performance. 
Disks with poor performance should be proactively removed from operation
and replaced with a new disk drive. \par 
Data Domain systems are backup servers that employ inline deduplication
technology on disk.  These systems use a RAID 6 algorithm with 14 disks per
disk group which offers protection against two disk failures.  Thus, the failure
of a third disk within a disk group would result in data loss.  This study utilizes data
from over 8,000 Data Domain systems containing more than 45,000 RAID
groups and 600,000 disk drives. \par
The \textit{usage statistic} is the ratio between the total time a disk is
utilized to process requests (e.g. reads, writes, or replications) and the
timestep $\Delta t$; it is used to indicate how busy a disk is during a
specified interval of time. \par
Formally, the \textit{usage} for disk $i$ over the timestamp $\Delta t =
t_{2}-t_{1}$, denoted $U_{i}$, is defined as

nexttext:
where $\mu_{\scriptscriptstyle\mathcal{U}}$ denotes the mean disk usage by
 group, and $\sigma_{\scriptscriptstyle\mathcal{U}}$ denotes the standard
 deviation.
 For example, for $\Delta t = 24$ hours, a usage observation of 0.5
 indicates that the disk spent a total of 12 out of 24 hours processing requests. \par 
 All the RAID groups used in this study from Data Domain systems contained
exactly 14 disks. We compare the observed z-scores with data generated 
from a standard normal distribution.
Figure~\ref{data_v_standard_normal} demonstrates the clear truncation and
nonnormality of the z-scores of disk usage compared to data from a standard normal distribution.  

\begin{figure}[H]
\centering
\includegraphics[height=5cm]{Zscore_Data.pdf}
\includegraphics[height=5cm]{Zscore_Simulated.pdf}
\caption{Comparison of data with Standard Normal}
\label{data_v_standard_normal}
\end{figure}

As shown in Figure~\ref{data_v_standard_normal}, z-scores do not exist larger
than 3.474 for a group of 14 disks.  In the following section, we prove that
this is not a data-specific phenomenon

\section{Mathematical Analysis of Maximum $Z-$scores}
\label{sec:anal}

In this section, we prove that the supremum of the possible z-scores for a
sample of size $n$ with $k$ outliers is finite for fixed $n$.
\begin{theorem}
Suppose $\{X_{i}\}_{i=1}^{n}$ is a random sample from a distribution
$\mathcal{D}$. Let the sample have $k < \lceil \frac{n}{2} \rceil$ outliers.
Then the z-scores $Z_{i}$ of the sample are uniformly bounded by $Z_{\pm b}$,
where $Z_{\pm b} = \pm \sqrt{\frac{(n-1)(n-k)}{nk}}$. In other words,
prevtext:
\label{Usage}

where $D_{i}(t)$, known as \textbf{disk ticks}, is the number of ticks (Unix
unit of time) that disk $i$ spent processing one or more requests, and $S(t)$
are \textbf{system ticks}. Then the z-score for disk $i$ is given by

nexttext:
\label{Zmax_theorem}
\end{theorem}
\begin{proof}
We first show the upper bound. Let $\{X_{[i]}\}_{i=1}^{n}$ be the order
statistics of $\{X_{i}\}_{i=1}^{n}$. $Z_{\max}$ is thus given by 
$Z_{\max} = \frac{X_{[n]}-\bar{X}}{\min(S_{n})}$
Suppose we have $k$ outliers. Since we seek the most extreme case, let
$X_{[n-k+1]} = X_{[n-k+2]} = \ldots = X_{[n]}.$ Let $\bar{X}_{n-k} =
\frac{1}{n-k}\sum_{i=1}^{n-k}X_{[i]} = 0$. If this is not the case, one may
shift the data by a constant $c$ such that this is true. Then
$\bar{X} = \frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}X_{i} = \frac{k}{n}X_{[n]}$
Now,

where $\mu_{\scriptscriptstyle\mathcal{U}}$ denotes the mean disk usage by
 group, and $\sigma_{\scriptscriptstyle\mathcal{U}}$ denotes the standard
 deviation.
 For example, for $\Delta t = 24$ hours, a usage observation of 0.5
 indicates that the disk spent a total of 12 out of 24 hours processing requests. \par 
 All the RAID groups used in this study from Data Domain systems contained
exactly 14 disks. We compare the observed z-scores with data generated 
from a standard normal distribution.
Figure~\ref{data_v_standard_normal} demonstrates the clear truncation and
nonnormality of the z-scores of disk usage compared to data from a standard normal distribution.  

\begin{figure}[H]

As shown in Figure~\ref{data_v_standard_normal}, z-scores do not exist larger
than 3.474 for a group of 14 disks.  In the following section, we prove that
this is not a data-specific phenomenon

Note: The double limit as $n,k \to \infty$ within the triangular
domain $k < \frac{n}{2}, k \geq 0, n \geq 0$ does not exist as seen by the two
limits above.

\subsubsection{$t-$score}
A similar analysis is done for $T_{\pm b}$. For fixed $n$, $\lim\limits_{k \to
\frac{n}{2}} = \sqrt{n-1}$. Therefore, as the number of possible outliers for a
fixed $n$ increases, the bounds narrow to $\sqrt{n-1}$. However, as $n \to
\infty$, even along the hypotenuse of the domain, the iterated limit $L =
\lim\limits_{n \to \infty}\lim\limits_{k \to
\frac{n}{2}}\sqrt{\frac{(n-1)(n-k)}{k}} = \infty$. Thus, unlike the $z-$score,
increasing the sample size even for the maximum number of outliers removes the
masking effect. 
\subsection{Sample Size Determination}

Using Theorem~\ref{Zmax_theorem}, we may determine for a potential number of
multiple outliers $k$ the sample size $n$ that will guarantee a range of
oberserved z-scores in a predetermined $Z_{\pm b}$. Fixing $k$ as the potential
number of outliers, let $Z$ be the upper (or lower, by symmetry) bound desired.
Then, solving ~\eqref{Zmax_theorem} for $n$, we may see that
prevtext:
Thus, for fixed $n$, as the number of outliers increases to $\lceil
\frac{n}{2}\rceil$, $Z_{\pm b} \to \sqrt{\frac{n-1}{n}}$, which approaches 1 as
the sample size increases to $\infty$. 

Now, fix $k=k_{0} < \frac{n}{2}$. Then

nexttext:
For example, if we want to use z-scores to detect outliers in a dataset where up
to 5 outliers are possible, and wish to exclude no more than $10^{-4}$ in the
tails, $|Z| = 4$. Plugging into~\eqref{eq: sample size determination}, we
require a sample size of at least 55 in order to overcome the masking effects of
up to 5 possible outliers.  Theorem~\ref{Zmax_theorem} provides a way to
quantitatively determine the appropriate sample size where one may employ the
use of z-scores for outlier detection.\par 


\section{Conclusion}
\label{sec:conc}
Outlier identification is a routine procedure in the analysis of data sets.
While many methods exist for the detection of multiple outliers in univariate
datasets, the z-score is still commonly employed due to its familiarity and
ease of use.  The employment of this statistic carries an assumption that the
sample data is approximately normal.  However, in small samples, the presence of
a single observation far from the mean violates the assumption of normality.  In our
experience, the normality assumption for small data sets is usually
inappropriate. The case study of performance degradation of HDDs in a RAID group
in Section~\ref{sec:case study} shows that the masking effect of multiple
outliers on a small sample can cause a system administrator to overlook
underperforming disks. 
\par
Theorem~\ref{Zmax_theorem} provides a closed form equation for the supremum of
possible z-scores for a given sample size and number of outliers. We also showed
via asymptotic analysis that an increase in the number of outliers for a fixed
$n$ amplifies the masking effect and virtually ensures tht none of the outliers
will be detected with any resonable level of confidence $\alpha$. This also
precipitated a simple corollary for the $t-$score. From the corollary,
outliers in a small sample may cause a masking effect due to the finite upper
bound induced. Thus, one should also use caution in employing $t-$scores for
outlier detection if the sample size is insufficiently large to overcome this
masking effect. The analogous asymptotic analysis for the $t-$score revealed
that, unlike the $z-$score bounds, increasing the sample size will eliminate
the truncation of the distribution, even for the maximum number of possible
outliers. In addition, the results of Theorem~\ref{Zmax_theorem} lead to the
proposition of a method for quantitatively defining a ``small sample'' using prior knowledge or estimation of the number of potential outliers that can be present in the sample. 
\bibliographystyle{Chicago}
\bibliography{Bibliography-MM-MC}
prevtext:
and thus we see that for a fixed number of outliers $k_{0}$, the masking effect
of the outliers disappears for large $n$, and thus z-scores are appropriate for
extremely large $n$. \par

Note: The double limit as $n,k \to \infty$ within the triangular
domain $k < \frac{n}{2}, k \geq 0, n \geq 0$ does not exist as seen by the two
limits above.

\subsubsection{$t-$score}
A similar analysis is done for $T_{\pm b}$. For fixed $n$, $\lim\limits_{k \to
\frac{n}{2}} = \sqrt{n-1}$. Therefore, as the number of possible outliers for a
fixed $n$ increases, the bounds narrow to $\sqrt{n-1}$. However, as $n \to
\infty$, even along the hypotenuse of the domain, the iterated limit $L =
\lim\limits_{n \to \infty}\lim\limits_{k \to
\frac{n}{2}}\sqrt{\frac{(n-1)(n-k)}{k}} = \infty$. Thus, unlike the $z-$score,
increasing the sample size even for the maximum number of outliers removes the
masking effect. 
\subsection{Sample Size Determination}

Using Theorem~\ref{Zmax_theorem}, we may determine for a potential number of
multiple outliers $k$ the sample size $n$ that will guarantee a range of
oberserved z-scores in a predetermined $Z_{\pm b}$. Fixing $k$ as the potential
number of outliers, let $Z$ be the upper (or lower, by symmetry) bound desired.
Then, solving ~\eqref{Zmax_theorem} for $n$, we may see that
